title: National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine (NCCAM) Introduction to Acupuncture with Disclaimer
author: Kendall; Donald E
description: Abstract. The United States National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine (NCCAM) has yet to confirm the validity of acupuncture. Organizations supporting nonsensical acupuncture ideas posted an article on the NCCAM website in December 2007 and updated on March 24, 2011. A public disclaimer notes that this information is not a substitute for medical advice or therapy and is not endorsed by the NCCAM. The article promotes physiologically incorrect acupuncture concepts created by Georges Soulié de Morant some 80 years ago involving the impossible idea of blood and energy circulating by invisible meridians. Chinese pnyn ( ) pronunciation guide terms have been adopted as a pretense that Soulié de Morant's bogus ideas were consistent with the original Chinese. These unfortunate misconceptions serve as a basis of almost all Western acupuncture training programs. The cited articles provide a clear challenge and opportunity to start providing correct science-based translations of those Chinese medicine terms that are most often misunderstood. The correct Chinese translation of key concepts noted in the 'Comments on Translations' section of this article indicates that the ancient Chinese had a keen understanding of the physiological basis of the original Chinese texts. Professional needle therapy/acupuncture training standards need to be upgraded to physiologically-based programs to best serve the public's interest.
